title: official-name-chosen-dunbars-bear-statue
story: The five-metre-tall steel sculpture on the outskirts of the town was unveiled last November.Created by renowned Scottish artist Andy Scott ndash also responsible for the Kelpies, near Falkirk ndash the county sculpture forms part of the Hallhill development on the townrsquos southern edge.Following the sculpturersquos unveiling, a competition was held with students from Belhaven Hill School, Dunbar Primary School and Dunbar Grammar School to name the bear.The winner, Emily Hotchkiss, an S pupil at Dunbar Grammar School, was chosen from nearly , entries, with her suggestion of The DunBear.One of her prizes was a picture of the bear signed by the artist.Ken Ross, from Hallhill Developments, said: ldquoIrsquom absolutely thrilled and would like to congratulate Emily Hotchkiss on her name for the bear.ldquoEvery entry represented real enthusiasm for the project and, at the end of the day, community, history and talent is what this unveiling has been about.ldquoThe DunBear celebrates the incredible legacy left behind by John Muir.ldquoHis advocacy for national parks and the environment in general is a lesson to us all that we must do what we can to protect our precious environment.ldquoGoing forward, we hope that many more children, young people and adults alike take an interest, visit and take an interest in The DunBear.The top  names from each school were selected by headteachers and passed to school prefects to narrow down the selection.The final name was chosen by Andy Scott and stakeholders from Hallhill Developments, which commissioned the piece.The sculpture, located off the A near the Spott Roundabout, is a nod to John Muir, who was born in the town in  and went on to play a key role in the development of Americarsquos national parks.He emigrated from Scotland in  and is famous for petitioning the US Congress for the National Park bill, establishing Yosemite National Park.The bear is symbolic of John Muirrsquos travels and his advocacy for national parks.The sculpture forms part of the mixed-use Hallhill development, which started on-site in .

title: tims-tales-kindness-butterfly
story: I WAS presented with incredible insight this week after I had told a tale in a P class. After the session, as the children were heading for lunch, a girl from the class came up and said: ldquoI think the moral in that tale is that we should be kind, but that itrsquos often not easy to do.It was a traditional tale in which the tables are turned on a selfish rich man who had shown no compassion, but then hoped for kindness when he was the one in need. In the brief discussion with this young person, we agreed that itrsquos easier to show kindness to someone who we believe truly deserves it.She told me: ldquoI think the woman in the story did the right thing butIrsquom being honest,it had been me I donrsquot knowIrsquod have been able to be kind like her, because Irsquod have wanted revenge. Thatrsquos the problem, I think, we always think about revenge first. It can make us feel better for a short while but really makes things worse, well at least not better anyway. I try to be kind, sometimes it isnrsquot easy, but I try. Kindness is like a seed we have to plant.I shouldnrsquot have been bowled over by this, for I know a -year-old can have wisdom that many so called grown-ups have forgotten. But I was deeply impressed by her reflection on the storyrsquos message, and her honesty and integrity.This conversation also revealed the power of stories to raise moral dilemmas and human issues without finger pointing or being preachy.And she is right, it can often be very dficult to be kind. The world seems so full of stress, selfishness, anger and intolerance that there seems little space for kindness, except towards those we love and care about. On top of that, it seems increasingly dficult to survive, keep a roof above our heads and pay the bills. Kindness begins at home and often there is little energy, emotion or resources left to think or care about others we arenrsquot responsible for.There can even be a real fear thatwe show lsquotoo muchrsquo kindness we risk becoming a doormat, being used or treated unfairly. We can sometimes watch a child being kind to another and it not being reciprocated, and the temptation then is to suggest kindness isnrsquot shown next time.ldquoWe need to teach people a lesson, is often the mantra which derails our instinct to be kind another way of saying we want revenge. And letrsquos be honest: cruel, uncaring and selfish people can take advantage of someonersquos kindness and revenge does often make us feel better, in the short term anyway.But is the answer to allow unkind behaviour to frame the way we want to live and be treated  Do we respond to unkindness with more unkindness in   So consequently, cruelty with more cruelty, intolerance with more intolerance, selfishness with yet more selfishness  Doesnrsquot this mean that we allow lsquothe lessonrsquo to be that kindness doesnrsquot pay  As Gandhi is famously reported to have said: ldquoAn eye for an eye only ends up making the whole world blind.The truth is, kindness is not weakness but strength. It often isnrsquot easy and takes great courage. It doesnrsquot mean that people should not face consequences for their actions, or that people should be asked to forgive the unforgivable. But it does mean not allowing the unkindness of others to define how we are. We should not allow such acts to clip our butterfly wings.What do I mean by this  There is a theory called the lsquobutterfly effectrsquo. In this theory, it is said that the flapping of a butterflyrsquos wings could cause a chain reaction in which a hurricane could be caused on the other side of the planet. It is not meant to be taken literally, but to show that a very small act, although seemingly insignicant in itself, can have huge, unforeseen repercussions.In this way, kindness is a butterfly. Small acts of kindness may have a huge effect that touches people beyond the knowledge of the person who displayed the kindness. Acts of cruelty and hate also have the same power but all the more reason to flutter the wings of kindness so the wind more likely blows in the right direction.In this way, our behaviour is a butterfly. The way we flap its wings can have huge unforeseeable consequences, either for good or bad, both for ourselves and others. When we are kind, we actually makes ourselves happier too.So to make a real dference, we need only do tiny acts that are easily within our power, and as often as we can. A smile, a moment you truly listen to someone, a helping hand, holding the door open, trying to understand how someone feels, making a cup of tea, not meeting anger with anger, trying not to gain revenge but a change of heart and so on.This is what will truly make up the index of a healthy and happy society. And all of us can be players in this, and beneficiaries of our own kindness.David W Orr, a professor of environmental studies and politics, has said: ldquoThe plain fact is that the planet does not need more successful people. But it does desperately need more peacemakers, healers, restorers, storytellers and lovers of every kind.Great words, but that -year-old school girl already got this. Young people like her give me hope for the future.

title: john-muir-house-car-park-opened-public
story: The car park, off Court Street, is home to about  spaces but can only be used by council employees and council HQ visitors between am and pm during the working week.That could soon change, with a number of spaces potentially being made available for public weekday daytime use.The idea comes as the council looks to increase the overall number of short and long stay car parking spaces in and around the town centre.Last year, discussions took place with members of the public surrounding the idea of creating a lsquotransport hubrsquo off the townrsquos Whittingehame Drive.Now, a further two-day consultation is taking place in Haddington Town House, when members of the public can discuss parking issues in the town.The consultation will focus on parking throughout Haddington, including possibly changing the long-stay car park near the townrsquos Tesco store into a short-stay car park.Tom Reid, head of infrastructure at East Lothian Council, said: ldquoFor many years, wersquove been keen to enhance the town centre so that it offers the best possible environment for all users ndash including people with restricted mobility, pedestrians and cyclists ndash to ensure easy access to the local services and businesses on which Haddington depends.ldquoAs well as improved options for active travel and public transport, we recognise there is a need to create more parking spaces in and around the town centre.ldquoFor this to happen, we need to change some existing parking from long stay to short stay, and deliver a new long-stay parking option for drivers who need to leave their vehicle in the town throughout the working day.ldquoOne proposal is the potential re-designation of the existing lsquoTesco long-stayrsquo car park, which could free up an additional  spaces in the town centre for short-stay, public parking.ldquoWe will also review the status of the car park at John Muir House, East Lothian Councilrsquos head office, to consider the potential for an area here to be available for wider public use.More than  people attended the previous exhibition in the Town House. At that time, the proposals showed a car park of up to  spaces at Whittingehame Drive, which would also include options for lsquopark and ridersquo, lsquopark and stridersquo, electric vehicle fast chargers, cycle parking and cycle hire.Last summer, East Lothian Council secured funding from the Scottish Governmentrsquos Town Centre Fund.Money secured for the project has to be spent by September this year and any proposals would need to go through the planning process.Mr Reid thanked everyone for their attendance at the meeting in December and encouraged people to go along to the upcoming consultation, which takes place on February  and , between pm and .pm each day.The events will be an opportunity to find out more about proposals to enhance parking provision and accessibility in Haddington town centre.There will be an exhibition of the transport hub site selection process and council officers will be available to discuss issues and record comments on the proposals and the wider issues regarding access to the town.Mr Reid added: ldquoTo continue providing dedicated, long-stay parking, wersquove been developing proposals to create a new edge-of-centre transport hub.ldquoThis would be linked to greater provision for sustainable and active travel choices, in support of our ambitions to reduce emissions.ldquoOption evaluation work has identied Whittingehame Drive as the most appropriate location.ldquoSeparately, the council has been looking at proposals to enhance the streetscape and public realm of the town centre, for the benefit of all users ndash including those on foot or travelling by bike.

title: gritter-fell-ditch-twice-one-night-clearing-east-lothian-roads

the crossroads near Danskine, just outside Gford.The driver was again unharmed he was picked up and ed home, while the gritter was recovered at about am on Tuesday, and continued on its route with title: msp-riverside-medical-practice-cannot-expand-boundary-issues-fixed
story: Colin Beattie MSP said this decision followed talks with Jeane Freeman MSP, Cabinet Secretary for Health and Sport.Last year, the Primary Care Contractor Organisation outlined plans to alter the practice boundary to take patients from the Blindwells new town development.Construction is set to get under way on the first of the , phase one homes at the former opencast mine site between Prestonpans and Longniddry.Over the next decade and beyond, up to , new homes and community facilities are expected to be built there.Also proposed is a ldquoLevenhall Queen Margaret University extension as part of the boundary change at the Riverside GP practice.The practice is based at Musselburgh Primary Care Centre , along with Inveresk Medical Practice, which is separate.After it merged with Eskbridge Medical Practice, Riverside became the largest practice in East Lothian and one of the biggest in Scotland, with about , patients.Mr Beattie said: ldquoFrom correspondence with local constituents, it was clear to me that action needed to be taken to remedy the ongoing issues in relation to Riverside Medical Practice.ldquoI have spoken with Jeane Freeman, the Cabinet Secretary for Health and Sport, who is now working closely with NHS Lothian to ensure that a solution is found.ldquoIt was decided that the best route forward was to allow no further boundary expansions of the practice until the service is ing at a satisfactory standard.ldquoI am sure that this decision will be welcomed by all those who have concerns about the practice.He added: ldquoOf course, the NHS does not have complete control over the operations of the practice, given that the doctors are simply contracted by the NHS to run this service. However, NHS Lothian will work closely with the management going forward to ensure their budget is managed more effectively, and that the issues at hand are adequately addressed.Members of Musselburgh and Inveresk Community Council have also told health bosses that the proposed boundary expansion would be ldquoa step in the wrong direction.The group contacted the Primary Care Contractor Organisation, stressing that it was ldquoabsolutely opposed to any change in the boundary area.Members also called for a meeting with health bosses, which took place recently at the practice and involved: Irene Tait, community council chairperson Margaret Stewart, community council secretary Holly Kilday, a community council member Dr Richard Fairclough and Dr Joana Stenke of Riverside Medical Practice ward councillors Stuart Currie and Katie Mackie Iain Gorman, East Lothian Health and Social Care Partnershiprsquos head of operations and Councillor Fiona OrsquoDonnell, chairperson of East Lothian Integration Joint Board.The community councillors highlighted complaints they had received from members of the community, including:A statement issued by the community council following the discussion said: ldquoWe wondered why on earth the practice would want to take on more of a workload when clearly they are not coping with what they have to deal with at present.ldquoThe practice acknowledged the fact that they had undergone many changes in the last few years, not least the fact that they are on their third telephone system.ldquoThe practice also stated they will need to step up to the mark with a communication plan, making sure that everyone in our community is aware of how the practice is working and what options are available to them.ldquoThe expectation from the public is,they phone for a doctorsrsquo appointment, they will see a doctor and this is not always going to be the case.ldquoWhen you call you will be given two options, same day or non-urgent, and this will enable the staff to put you on to the right person who can help and this could be NHS , paramedics, physio, mental health or occupational therapistor alternatively, a doctornecessary on the same day.Wrong direction ldquoWe discussed the boundaries and made them aware that we felt that to take on Blindwells would be a step in the wrong direction.ldquoThe meeting was quite positive and hopefully, moving forward, we will keep in touch with the practice and they with us so that everyone is kept informed.Dr Stenke and Dr Fairclough issued a joint statement, saying: ldquoWe were delighted to meet with the Musselburgh and Inveresk Community Council representatives and local councillors. We felt it was a really positive opportunity to discuss many of the changes that have happened in Musselburgh over the last few years to stabilise and develop primary care services.ldquoIt is really important for us at Riverside to understand the views of the community we serve, which can be hugely supportive in improving services. For example, feedback on our old phone system helped us to understand the issues that our patients were experiencing and led to us developing a new telephone system that was more suitable for our patientsrsquo needs as well as those of the practice.ldquoRiverside, along with other practices in the county, are collaborating with and supporting East Lothianrsquos Health and Social Care Partnershiprsquos plan to grow health services to meet the needs of a growing population.ldquoWe remain keen to improve our engagement and communication with the local community, and the meeting was a positive step to build links with local groups.ldquoWe are grateful to the community council representatives and local councillors for taking the time to visit us at Riverside Medical Practice and we look forward to developing a closer and collaborative relationship with them.An East Lothian Health and Social Care Partnership spokesperson said: ldquoWe thought the meeting with Riverside and the community council was very positive. We were impressed by Riversidersquos commitment to engaging with the community and communicating developments. We look forward to supporting them in any way that we can.Councillor Mackie added: ldquoIt was a helpful meeting with community stakeholders and local GPs. There was recognition that previous changes to the Riverside practice could have been better communicated to patients and a real willingness to improve engagement with the local community.ldquoHopefully this is the start of really meaningful engagement with local GPs at Riverside.

title: claim-buildings-haddington-street-left-shaking-large-vehicles
story: Concerns about the speed of vehicles and the condition of the buildings on the historic street were raised at Haddingtonrsquos community council meeting.Members heard from David Barrett, who lives near the busy town centre street and felt that something needed to be done.However, he claimed he had raised the issue with East Lothian Council previously ndash only to allegedly be told that nothing could be done until the buildings started falling onto the street.Mr Barrett said: ldquoI think one of the paradoxes about Market Street is we all see it during the day and Friday afternoon, it is more like Oxford Circus. You can walk faster than the traffic.ldquoBut between am and am, and between pm and am, huge agricultural vehicles and HGVs actually hit  miles plus per hour through the town and our buildings shake, they physically shake.Mr Barrett was keen to see something done to slow vehicles down on the busy street.He said: ldquoIrsquom suggesting that some type of traffic calming is very necessary to preserve the fabric of the historic buildings.However, the idea of large vehicles doing more than  miles per hour on Market Street was refuted by Rab Moran.The community councillor, who was an HGV driver for about  years, said: ldquoI used to be an HGV driver and there is no way an articulated lorry or anything  for that matter clatters along Market Street at  miles per hour.ldquoYou sometimes donrsquot get up to  miles per hour going along there.Mr Moran stressed that it was a rural community and there were occasions where farm machinery needed to use the roads.Fellow community councillor Chris McEwan said there were issues with putting in traffic calming measures, such as speed humps.He said: ldquoSpeed humps are going to be absolutely useless to anything over a normal car size.ldquoThey are designed so ambulances can carry over.ldquoThey would not slow down trucks or anything .A spokeswoman for East Lothian Council confirmed that the issue was being investigated.She said: ldquoWe are aware of Mr Barrettrsquos concerns and have advised that the council is currently looking at measures concerning traffic movement in and around Haddington.ldquoThese plans may include consideration of traffic calming options to reduce speeds in certain areas.

title: met-office-name-storms-names-ruled
story: After a mild start to the year, we have been battered by heavy rain and severe gales.But who comes up with the names for storms and whats next Why do the Met Office name storms The Met Office first decided to givestorms a namein  with the first one named Abigail in November .The hope was that naming severe storms wouldmake people more aware of them and how dangerous they can be.And it makes iteasier to follow the progress of a storm on the TV, radio, or on social media,it has a name.Can I suggest a storm name Every summer the Met Office andMet Eacuteireann askpeople to send in their ideas for future storm names.Look out for their #NameOurStorms campaign on social media around July this year for the chance for your name to be included.A new list of names will be compiled jointly between Met Eacuteireann,the Met Office and KNMIin September for the following   storm season.What are the storm names for this year Weve already had:Dennis is set to arrive this weekend and then weve got:Names alternate between male and female and run from A-Z based on some of the more popular names suggested to the Met Office as well as reflecting the ersity of Britain, Ireland and the Netherlands.To ensure the Met Office is in line with the US National Hurricane Centre naming conventions, names which begin with the letters Q, U, X, Y and Z are not included.Are there any names the Met Office has ruled out Among the names suggested to the Met Office, officials have rejected anything that isnt a proper name.That includes:Apocalypse, Baldrick, Big Boss, Gnasher, Hot Brew, root ripper, Stormageddon, Ssswetcaroline, Vader, Voldermort and branch wobbler.Other rejected names included Hammer, Hades,Forkbeard, Megatron andIn A Teacup.

title: tims-tales-gift-magic-space
story: A STORYTELLER friend recently gted us an articial electric log stove and hearth surround with mantle piece.She is an expert at recycling, and placed it where the real fireplace used to be and it looks fantastic. When the fire effect is switched on, it gives an impressive imitation of a real one.Our small terraced house once had a real fire place, of course, but like so many it was modernised before I moved in, and it was filled in and central heating installed.Yet I am old enough to have lived all my childhood in the lsquos and lsquos without experiencing central heating! It did exist, of course, just not in the houses I lived in as a child!One memory I have is of arriving home from school on a cold winterrsquos afternoon and seeing the smoke coming from the chimney of the church house we lived in at the east end of the Pans. My father had lit the fire early and I still remember its welcoming warmth, and the way it crackled and danced as it defrosted my face and hands. Me and my brothers sat by it, jostling for the best space.Donrsquot get me wrong, Irsquom not complaining about central heating! I know Irsquom lucky to have a warm house and never take it for granted. We donrsquot use the lsquofirersquo for heat, that would be too expensive. But we switch it on for atmosphere. And the effect on the younger kids has been immediate. They sit by it, lie on blankets by it reading and playing and telling stories. I forget that they have little personal experience of having a hearth, even an articial one. The novelty will wane, perhaps, but I hope the cosy pleasure of it wonrsquot.Itrsquos not just the kids, as my we and I love sitting by it in the evening. Wersquove even moved some of the furniture, so this pretend but convincing fireplace, rather than the telly, has become the main focal point of the living room.You could say Irsquom easily pleased, and I suppose thatrsquos true. But our friends have commented on it too, one saying ldquoit really has given your house a dferent atmosphere as he sat by it with the wind howling outside.The hearth has traditionally been the soul of a house. The family would sit by it, soak in the warmth and watch the flames, while telling stories and talking. It was a draw for social communion. Visitors would be welcomed with a place by it and most of the cooking would have taken place there too. The old saying ldquolang may yer lums reekindicated the importance of a lit hearth as a symbol of wellbeing and good fortune.No wonder so many traditions and ceremonies were centred around the hearth. People used to leave objects buried within or near it. There were ious reasons for this: to capture bad spirits that may come down the chimney, for good luck or to deflect a witchrsquos spell. The hearth was seen as a kind of spiritual portal, to be defended and made safe, not just physically.The hearth was also a focus of many ceremonies that marked the changing seasons. The Celtic calendar is full of such events, Imbolc being the most recent. And of course there were the daily rituals of banking up the fire at night, and reviving it in the morning, and keeping it going. All these simple tasks are now fast fading into folk memory.Today, screens are more likely to be the focal point of our homes. Itrsquos kind of unavoidable, of course, and I claim no moral high ground of this issue. But the truth is they drug our senses and dull our conviviality, and, like many parents, we have tried to limit their use in our house. It has felt like a losing battle with my children who, I understand, live in a very dferent childhood to mine. And I readily concede itrsquos got lots of benefits, even though at times I may sound like an old dinosaur lamenting the passing of the Jurassic age.But the arrival of our fake woodburning stove has transformed our house in a way that shows we have lost something in the lsquomodernisingrsquo of our homes. As a storyteller, I have come to understand the importance of a hearth as a focal point for gathering it has the power to bring people together, to share warmth and light but also each otherrsquos presence and social connection. As the freezing wind rages outside, it is a magical space.That magic has been the true gt from my storyteller friend, and she wisely knew it. While much is missing from an articial fire, including the smell and sound of the real thing, our ancestral instinct still kicks in by the visual sight of a flickering hearth.So now my instructions to switch off the screens is more readily obeyed, because it signals time to get together around the fire and lsquobe together properlyrsquo to tell stories and challenge each other with riddles.Burnrsquos poem The Cotterrsquos Saturday Night now has new meaning in our house:To meet their dad, wi flichterin noise and glee.His wee bit ingle, blinkin bonilie,His clean hearth-stane, his thrty wiersquos smile,The lisping infant, prattling on his knee,Does arsquo his weary kiaugh and care beguile,An makes him quite forget his labor and his toil.

title: waterside-bistro-chief-takes-castle-inn-dirleton
story: Brothers Jack and James Findlay have been at the helm of the Waterside Bistro, next to the River Tyne in Haddington, for more than two-and-a-half years.The eaterie was founded by their dad Jim, who also previously ran The Drovers Inn in East Linton, and The Rocks on Dunbarrsquos Marine Road.Now, Jack is expanding the empire by taking over The Castle Inn.He told the Courier: ldquoWe have had quite a soft opening, we just opened yesterday [last Wednesday].ldquoI think the area is lovely and my dad was born in Dirleton, so there is a little bit of heritage there.ldquoWe will be basing it a lot on the Waterside model and obviously myself and my brother will be working alongside each other but from afar.ldquoWe have had tremendous success at the Waterside and we both felt it was probably the right time to look where.ldquoThe Castle Inn was the perfect fit for us.ldquoIt will be myself here and my brother is still based in Haddington.ldquoMy dad is lsquoretiredrsquo but will just be popping in and making sure we are going in the right direction.Twenty-eight-year-old Jack said they already had a good team in place and there were no plans for any ldquodrastic changes.A focus would be placed on locally sourced food, with a daily list of specials.He added: ldquoI would also like to mention the former owners John Dawson and Bert DrsquoAgostino, and want to pay a bit of a tribute to them for their fine work in the trade.ldquoJohn has been fantastic with me and very helpful.

title: bench-put-place-memory-tranent-legend-bobby-marr
story: Bobby Marr, who ran a greengrocer and florist on Tranentrsquos Winton Place for nearly  years, passed away last July.The -year-old was a familiar face to many in Tranent town centre, with hundreds attending his funeral.Marion Hoggan was heavily involved in the fundraising for the bench for Mr Marr, who had colon cancer.She said: ldquoI did not manage the funeral due to work commitments and I felt that I wanted to do something for him. I came up with the idea of the bench and spoke to the family and they were quite keen on it.ldquoMyself and a couple of friends did a fundraising day at the Store Club on January .ldquoIt was a sell-out ndash it sold out within a week of talking about it ndash and a lot of people did not get tickets.ldquoDavid Martin was the host and we had Derryn McKillop, Jim McCran, Donna Howe, Jack Robertson, Dean Jones and Mags Foster there.ldquoThey all entertained us all day, free of charge, and gave up their precious time.In total, the event raised more than pound,, with any money above the cost of the bench being donated to the oncology department at the Western General Hospital in Edinburgh.Mrs Hoggan described Mr Marr, who lived on the townrsquos Kennedy Crescent, as ldquovery kind and ldquoa true gentleman and said he always took an interest in the bowling exploits of her daughters Kim and Dee.She thanked local businesses and shopkeepers for the donation of raffle prizes and cash donations for the fundraiser last month.She also paid tribute to David Forrest and Tranent and Elphinstone Community Council for working alongside East Lothian Council to see the bench put in place.Mr Forrest, chairman of the townrsquos community council, was also among those at the unveiling ceremony off the townrsquos High Street.He said: ldquoI remember Bobby Marr in his shop and I remember when his parents owned it. I was at school with Bobbyrsquos older brother and Bobby was always a nice bloke, always friendly and always helpful.ldquoThe shop has been part of Tranent for as long as I have been in Tranent.More than  people turned out off Tranent High Street at the war memorial on Tuesday afternoon for the unveiling of the bench.Councillor Kenny McLeod, who lives in the town, was among those at the short ceremony, which took place on what would have been Mr Marrrsquos th birthday.Mr McLeod was delighted with the event and felt it was a fitting gesture.He said: ldquoThere was a big turnout of about  folk.

title: independent-scotland-overtake-countries-swiftly-join-eu-says-expert
story: James Ker-Lindsay, a visiting professor at the London School of Economics, said Scotland could ldquoovertake the other countries in short order and join the EU relatively quickly.The SNP, which is pushing for the power to hold a second independence referendum, said the intervention demolished ldquoone of the Unionist myths from .There have been repeated claims that an independent Scotland would have to join the back of the queue for EU membership.:Senior Tories want a second referendum claims former party spin doctorIn , then prime minister David Cameron said it would have to ldquoqueue up as it were behind other countries ndash for instance those in the western Balkans that are already on the path towards membership.But Prof Ker-Lindsay said no policy maker ldquowould put Scotland in the same basket as the western Balkans.He said there are currently just three formal candidates for EU membership: Montenegro, Serbia and Turkey.Two more countries, North Macedonia and Albania, are in line to start accession talks.In a blog post published by the Scottish Centre on European Relations, Prof Ker-Lindsay said: ldquoIn terms of the political framework, there is no doubt that Scotland stands apart from the countries currently in the queue.ldquoIn every way, the historical, political, economic and even social contexts are completely dferent.He said the western Balkans are scarred by the conflicts of the s, while there are still unresolved issues such as ldquothe relationship between Kosovo and Serbia, and the political deadlock in Bosnia.Problems around the rule of law, democratic institutions and the economy also remain in some areas.The academic wrote: ldquoLeaving aside the fact that Scotland was part of the EU for  years by virtue of British membership, the dferences between Scotland and the western Balkans could not be starker.He said this all meant EU members ldquowill almost certainly treat Scotland very dferently when it comes to making the political decisions about whether or not to open accession talks.Prof Ker-Lindsay wrote: ldquoHowever, while the political framework could not be more dferent, one would imagine that the formal negotiating process will have to remain essentially the same.ldquoThe Commission would assess the situation in terms of each chapter and report back on whether convergence exists. It would then be for members to make their decisions.:The UK will neverto the European Union says David MartinldquoThat said, one cannot overlook the specic circumstances that would arise in the case of Scotland.He said the process of an independent Scotland re-joining the EU could be ldquorelatively straightforward and swt, assuming there is no major ergence between the EU and UK after the Brexit transition period.The expert said: ldquoUltimately,the member states wish to acknowledge the fundamental dferences that exist between Scotland and the Western Balkans, and adjust the wider framework of negotiations, they can ndash and I suspect would ndash do so.ldquoTo this extent, any claim that Scotland would have to go to the back of the queue may be theoretically correct, but only as a simple statement of fact. At the moment of independence, it would not have taken any of the steps to join that the others have done.:Scottish independence support maintains lead in latest pollldquoHowever, it would almost certainly be moved to the fast track line. From there, it would still be subject to the same checks as everyone . However, assuming the paperwork is all in order and there havenrsquot been many or signicant ergences, one would expect it to overtake the other countries in short order and join the EU relatively quickly.Keith Brown, the SNPrsquos deputy leader, said the comments were ldquoyet another intervention demolishing one of the Unionist myths from .He said: ldquoPeople in Scotland overwhelmingly voted to stay in the EU ndash and despite being dragged out against our will by a Tory government with no mandate here, Scotland remains a European country with European values.ldquoThere is now unstoppable momentum for a referendum, and the ability to protect our place at the heart of Europe.ldquoScotland must have the chance to choose our own future as an independent, European nation.

title: 1m-research-climate-change-affecting-scotlands-peatlands
story: Dr Roxane Andersen, from the Environmental Research Institute at North Highland College UHI, will use the pound, funding to explore how climate change could affect blanket bogs and to assess the effectiveness of restoration efforts.The research leadership award, provided by the Leverhulme Trust, will enable Dr Andersen to develop a team of nine researchers, who will conduct the investigations over a five-year period.They will use cutting-edge technologies and techniques, including satellite remote sensing, to investigate how we can protect and restore blanket bog areas. Peatlands are renowned for their ability to soak up carbon dioxide from the atmosphere, to promote bioersity and to provide high quality water.The Thurso-based scientists will benefit from access to the Flow Country, the largest blanket bog in Europe and a region that is under consideration for World Heritage Site status ndash joining the ranks of Australiarsquos Great Barrier Reef, the Grand Canyon in America and the Taj Mahal in India.The project will also support new initiatives across the universityrsquos research centres and foster national and international collaborations, including work with Canadian peatland research groups.Dr Andersen said: ldquoPeatlands are the Earthrsquos most efficient terrestrial carbon store. They regulate water and climate and support unique bioersity.ldquoHowever, their degradation affects the delivery of these key s. In the UK, the cool, wet climate supports a globally rare peatland type: blanket bogs.ldquoMost UK blanket bogs have been degraded by human activities and, left alone, they make a signicant contribution to our greenhouse gas emissions from the land use sector. However, unprecedented efforts to restore our blanket bogs are under way, for example through the Peatland Action programme in Scotland.ldquoAstonishingly, we do not know the extent to which these interventions work or how blanket bogs, restored or otherwise, will cope with the added threat of climate change.ldquoI am thrilled to have been chosen by the Leverhulme Trust for this Research Leadership Award. I look forward to working with my team to pioneer approaches from molecular to landscape scales to fill some of these gaps in our knowledge and to inform UK and global peatland management strategies.The project will focus on three key areas of research. The team will explore how environmental conditions can affect Sphagnum mosses, one of the building blocks of peat in blanket bog.They will continue to develop a method that uses satellite data to measure how the seasonal patterns of swelling and shrinking of bog surface, known as ldquobog breathing, change in response to climate extremes and restoration activities. They will also work to refine models that predict how blanket bogs may respond to dferent management approaches in future climate change scenarios.Emma Goodyer, manager of the International Union For The Conservation Of Nature Uk Peatland Programme, said: ldquoThe area covered by near natural peatland worldwidestores more carbon than all other vegetation types in the world combined. However, drained and damaged peatlands contribute about  per cent of greenhouse gas emissions from the land use sector annually, despite covering only .% of the global land surface.ldquoScotland has become a global leader in peatland management. The research hub in the Flow Country has been instrumental in delivering programmes of research that tackle some of the most pressing issues for peatland restoration and policy. This signicant funding boost will offer the opportunity to understand the resilience of peatland ecosystems in the face of the climate crisis whilst also reversing bioersity losses.The Flow Country of Caithness and Sutherland has bogs in the tundra-like landscape that have been growing since the end of the last Ice Age more than , years ago. The arearsquos peat is up to ft deep and its soil stores about  million tons of carbon.Wildle in the area include otters, deer and common scoter ducks.In the UK, common scoters breed at only a few locations, including the Flow Country and the lochs and and glens near Inverness.Six of the UKrsquos  World Heritage sites are in Scotland.

title: radical-gaelic-campaign-group-reveals-plans-stand-raft-local-election-candidates
story: Misneachd ndash which translates as confidence or courage ndash says all adults in the Western Isles and other Gaelic heartlands should have the right to six monthsrsquo free, full-time tuition in the language in islands-based ldquoimmersion centres.This would take the form of a paid sabbatical for those in work.It also wants to phase out English-medium education in the islands and limit the number of second homes.Misneachd is fielding a candidate for the first time in a local by-election on Skye on March , following the resignation of independent councillor Professor Ronald MacDonald from Highland Council.:Alan Simpson: It is time to rip up the Gaelic blueprint and start againMagravertainn Mac a Bhagraveillidh, the grouprsquos candidate, told the Herald on Sunday: "I think in the next council elections we want to have a raft of candidates standing in the islands, again as independents but with an affiliationto the Misneachd agenda as it were, rather than as an official political party."Its just very hard to challenge the status quo in terms of language policies. All the parties are kind of equally weak on the subject, and theres very little in terms of policy debate."The -year-old said the group had discussed registering as a political party but currently favour fielding independent candidates in the Highlands and islands linked to its agenda.He said the prospect of putting candidates forward for Holyrood elections is also "under discussion", adding: "It would be quite a big step. It would be good to do, but as an organisation, we are completely reliant on donations and we would need to run fundraisers and whatnot for it. Potentially ndash but maybe next years a bit too soon."It comes amid continuing debate over Gaelicrsquos future, with the quango in charge of the language, Bograverd na Gagraveidhlig, facing criticism over a lack of openness and transparency.Last month, Western Isles council - Comhairle nan Eilean Siar - announced children starting school this year will be taught in Gaelic, unless their parents opt-out.Misneachdrsquos Radical Plan for Gaelic, published in , warned the language is rapidly dying out in its Hebridean heartlands, and accused Gaelic organisations and politicians of being complacent and in denial.It argued: ldquoThe historical and continuing decline of Gaelic-speaking communities constitutes an ongoing process of cultural genocide over many centuries.ldquoSimilar injustices have been recognised as such in other parts of the world, and we must likewise be prepared to state the stark truth of the situation with regard to Gaelic communities.ldquoCurrent politicians are allowing this great historical injustice to continuethey do not take sufficient steps to halt and reverse this process.The group called for an ambitious target of attaining  per cent bilingualism in Gaelic and English among all those who have been resident in the Western Isles for at least five years.Its Gaelic plan stated: ldquoAll adults in the Western Isles and other Gaelic heartlands should have the right to six months free full-time Gaelic tuition ndash in the form of a paid sabbatical for those in work.Elsewhere, Misneachd argued grants should be introduced for parents raising their children in Gaelic ldquoon the lines of schemes formerly in place in Ireland, and advocated ldquoGaelic-medium housing developments.Its Radical Plan for Gaelic argued: ldquoWhile we do not claim to have devised a comprehensive plan that contains all that is necessary to maintain Gaelic as a living language for generations to come, we are certain that without drastic and urgent reform of the policy status quo Scotland is acquiescing to the imminent death of Gaelic as a community language, an act of supreme negligence which can only be described as cultural vandalism of a most crass kind, not to mention cultural genocide against an indigenous minority.Misneachd said it will be campaigning in Skye for parents to be legally entitled to Gaelic medium education for their children between the ages of three and , wherever possible in stand-alone Gaelic schools.It also wants a land value tax and controls over holiday homes and rent prices.The group called for more social and affordable housing for rural areas, investment in infrastructure, and a reform of councils.It said: ldquoLocal democracy in Scotland is broken. Our councils are far too large compared to most European countries.ldquoSmaller councils should be established with a strong link between people and those who rule them.ldquoRural Gaels should also be empowered through a democratic Gaelic assembly, similar to the Saami parliaments in the Scandinavian countries and the proposed Daacuteil na nGael in Ireland.:Scottish Gaelic set to be introduced on free language learning appMac a Bhagraveillidh ndash whose English name is Martin Baillie ndash was involved in the recent creation of the popular Gaelic Duolingo course, a free online language learning service.He said Misneachd is ldquonot expecting all the policies and all the things we put forward to be put into practice in the short-term, but the debate around what is being done to help preserve Gaelic is very stale and theres very little blue sky thinking or any thinking at all ndash its just proceed as was.The architect, who is originally from Glasgow but now lives in Skye, said many of the grouprsquos policies are already in place in Wales.He said: "Its radical in a context of Gaelic language policy, but less so in a minority language context, even within the UK."He said "very, very little" is currently spent on Gaelic, and argued that while tourism is a good thing, the Highlands and Islands are often ldquotreated like a theme park for people to come and look at.Misneachd argues that although the concept of "cultural genocide" is not an established part of international law, it was defined in an early draft of the UNs Genocide Convention in the s.Ruraidh Stewart, the Scottish Tory candidate in the Skye by-election, argued Gaelic should not be politicised and questioned the feasibility of some of Misneachdrsquos policies.He said: ldquoThe councils as it is are short of money, and thatrsquos come from the Scottish Government freezing the budget for the councils, in essence.ldquoWe do have a finite amount of money. What I believe is we should be promoting the local services, such as the schools, the hospitals, repairing the roads.Fay Thomson, the Liberal Democrat candidate, said she agreed with much of what Misneachd said in relation to extra investment and promotion for Gaelic.However, she also questioned the feasibility of some policies, and said Misneachd appeared ldquosomewhat militant in their approach, and Irsquom not sure thatrsquos the best way to go about saving a language.She said: ldquoI think you have to be practical when yoursquore looking at solutions.Thomson said her priorities would be investment in roads, schools and health services.The council by-election is also being fought by the SNP, the Greens and an independent candidate, Calum Munro.A Scottish Government spokeswoman said Gaelic is ldquoa vital part of Scotlandrsquos cultural identity".She said: ldquoWe support all our indigenous languages, including Gaelic, as we recognise the cultural, economic, educational, health and social benefits that they bring to the whole of Scotland.ldquoIt is now easier than ever before to get access to teaching aids with the new Duolingo course and the recently updated Learn Gaelic website offering a wealth of a materials.She said there are around , Gaelic speakers in Scotland and just under , of those are based in the Western Isles.

title: senior-tories-want-second-referendum-claims-former-party-spin-doctor
story: The idea of holding another vote has always been a firmly rejected by party leaders, with the official stance of "No to Indyref" appearing throughout the general election campaign of last year.The partys new leader, Jackson Carlaw, has also said he is against holding a second referendum.However Andy Maciver, the partys former head of communications and now director of think tank Message Matters, said he has been in several conferences and talks with leading party members who say they are in favour of holding another vote on the constitution.The former adviser said: "The reality of next year is that it is all about how the Scottish Conservatives deal with indyref."There is one camp who thinks they have to say yes to indyref, and the other are saying It was once in a generation, the SNP are mucking up the country and people will realise that.:Jackson Carlaw elected new leader of Scottish Conservatives"I have been involved in conferences on both sides here, but there are very senior people on both sides of this and that is a problem for the Tories."That is the biggest thing Jackson Carlaw has to deal with."Many of the Scottish Tories have got a hope that the SNP have got policy problems, in education and so on. To a degree they are right but its wishful thinking that those issues are going to impact on election voting patterns."The SNP are still polling at % almost, so they cannot be called a government in trouble."The reality is, the SNP will want to make the next election about indyref, the media will want to make it about indyref, so its going to be about indyref. The Tories can go and do a school visit on a Tuesday afternoon, but the first question they get will be on indyref."They need to work out what to do.""@context": "https:schema.org","@type": "VideoObject","name": "Carlaw elected as Scottish Conservatives leader","description": "Carlaw elected as Scottish Conservatives leader","thumbnailUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer v media rIOddQP poster.jpg width","uploadDate": "--T::+:","duration": "PDTHMS","contentUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer manests rIOddQP.mu","embedUrl": "https:www.heraldscotland video  ","publisher": "@type": "Organization","name": "HeraldScotland","logo": "@type": "ImageObject","url": "https:www.heraldscotland sitelogo ","width": ,"height": It comes as the Scottish Tories enter a new era under veteran politician Carlaw, who defeated his opponent Michelle Ballantyne with % of the  votes by party members. Just % of eligible voters took part in the election.He celebrated his victory on Friday with a congratulatory phone call from Boris Johnson, followed shortly afterwards by the announcement of a raft of new appointees to senior roles.They included Glasgow MSP Annie Wells as joint deputy leader alongside North East MSP Liam Kerr, and Rachael Hamilton, MSP for Ettrick, Roxburgh and Berwickshire, becoming joint party chairwoman with existing chairman Rab Forman.It is believed Carlaw made the appointments to provider greater gender balance to the party, while offering well-performing female MSPs the chance to gain more experience.Sources who spoke to The Herald on Sunday said there could be a raft of changes next week as Carlaw announces his new shadow cabinet, with Wells expected to be given a promotion from her existing role as Equalities spokeswoman. Jamie Greene, MSP for West Scotland and transport spokesman, has also been tipped for promotion.Miles Briggs, the partys health spokesman, and Liam Kerr, who looks after justice, are both expected to play a role in the new top team, albeit in dferent positions than they hold now, however less experienced MSPs, it has been suggested, could make an appearance too.One Scottish Conservative source said that Carlaw "would not want to rock the boat" at this stage in his leadership, while another said there would be "major changes to the shadow cabinet" next week, focused mainly on rearranging the existing members rather than sacking people.:Scottish independence support maintains lead in latest pollAnother source suggested Ballantyne, who lost the leadership race, would have no place in the top tier at Holyrood, nor would she be expecting one. She is currently the partys social security spokeswoman.The party insider said: "If the vote had been closer, and there were more people in favour of Michelle for leader, there would be a bit of an onus on Jackson to give her a senior position but at this stage there is absolutely no need for him to do it."It just dependshe thinks Michelle will be more of a threat to him by being in the shadow cabinet, or out of it. I dont think he would want someone who ran against him in the leadership contest to then be working alongside him on key campaign and policy strategy, but who knows."Speaking to The Herald on Sunday, Carlaw appeared to avoid the IndyRef question altogether, focusing instead on his plans for the Holyrood elections.He said: "The campaign for Holyrood  is only a year away from launching, and the hard work very much starts now.ldquoWersquoll be reviewing our policies, announcing some key changes to those policies, and moving people into the right place for a campaign that aims to win.ldquoPeople know the SNP has been neglecting the day job, and itrsquos now down to us to prove to them that we will go about the day job in a far better way.ldquoItrsquos now time for Scotland to move on from constitutional ision and focus on the things that really matter.ldquoAfter  years, the SNP is in a downward spiral ndash a government which is morally and politically bankrupt.ldquoItrsquos time for a change at the top.

title: caroline-flack-love-island-tv-stars-pay-tribute-presenter
story: Her family said in a statement: ldquoWe can confirm that our Caroline passed away today, the th of February.ldquoWe would ask that the press respect the privacy of the family at this dficult time and we would ask they make no attempt to contact us and or photograph us.The shock news prompted a flood of tributes from celebrities but also questions about the pressures faced by TV celebrities and about the decision to press ahead with her prosecution for an alleged assault on her boyfriend.:TV presenter Caroline Flack found dead aged Flack, , stepped down from presenting the current Love Island show after she was alleged to have assaulted Lewis Burton , at her then flat in Islington, north London, in December.She entered a not guilty plea to the assault charge at Highbury Corner Magistratesrsquo Court and she was released on bail, with conditions that stopped her having any contact with Burton ahead of a trial in March.In a statement released on Saturday night her management company criticised the Crown Prosecution Service for pressing ahead with what it called her ldquoshow trial even after her boyfriend said he did not support it.Francis Ridley of Money Talent Management, said: ldquoIn recent months Caroline had been under huge pressure because of an ongoing case and potential trial which has been well reported.ldquoThe Crown Prosecution Service pursued this when they knew not only how very vulnerable Caroline was but also that the alleged victim did not support the prosecution and had disputed the CPS version of events.ldquoThe CPS should look at themselves today and how they pursued a show trial that was not only without merit but not in the public interest. And ultimately resulted in signicant distress to Caroline.The tragedy will also put the spotlight back on the pressures which come with TV celebrity.Flack is the fourth person linked to ITV dating programme Love Island to have killed themselves.Sophie Gradon, who appeared as a contestant in the show in , was found dead at her home in  at the age of .Her boyfriend Aaron Armstrong, who had found her body, killed himself three weeks later. story: The First Minister spoke exclusively to The Sunday Times Magazine, where she reaffirmed her plans to hold indyref before the end of .Her plans have previously been met with backlash by the Prime Minister, however Sturgeon has now said a vote this year is entirely possible.ldquoA referendum can absolutely happen this year, she told The Sunday Times. ldquoLetrsquos see what happens over the next few weeks.The SNP leader also hinted that an unsanctioned wildcat referendum would be a last resort, and that Brexit could cause an acceleration of support for independence, which she describes as something of a tipping point.:Labour candidates quizzed on indyref as leadership hustings held in GlasgowHowever, she admitted that an independent Scotland would not always be simple or straightforward."I have self-doubt about things every day," she said. "I would hate to be somebody who had such absolute certainty that I didnt entertain the idea that I might be wrong about things."So, of course I think about it. I dont believe that it will always mean plain sailing for Scotland."I just think its right to be independent to have the best chance."She claimed that Boris Johnsons opposition to independence was aiding her goal of building support for the cause.:Kevin McKenna: SNPrsquos female talent deserves better than lsquotrans warriorrsquo abuseShe said of the prime minister: "He is a democracy denier. And while I can be impatient, I know that how he is behaving will ultimately drive people towards the independence cause."Boris Johnson is one of the biggest recruiting sergeants for independence there is at the moment."And she says that England will have masses to gain from losing Scotland."England gains a neighbour that is best friends and a constructive partener," she explained.

title: rishi-sunak-push-back-budget-day-considers-turning-treasury-spending-taps
story: The Transport Secretary said ministers had still not been told whether the Budget would go ahead on March  as planned after Sajid Javids shock resignation.Mr Shapps also sought to downplay what many regard as Mr Javidrsquos forced departure, stressing how all ministers should be working hand in glove with Downing St and should not be in ldquodferent silos.He also insisted it was ldquonot correct to suggest Dominic Cummings, Boris Johnsonrsquos chief strategist, was running the No  show.:Devolved administrations send joint letter to Treasury seeking Budget talksMr Cummings and Mr Javid clashed several times in the seven months the Midlands MP was at the helm of the Treasury. The Prime Ministerrsquos key adviser was said to be pressing for the Treasury to turn on the spending taps, which the Chancellor was reluctant to do.Mr Shapps denied Mr Cummings was now "all powerful" in Whitehall, pointing out how last weeks decision to give the go ahead to the HS high speed rail link was a project opposed by Mr Johnsonrsquos top aide.However, Sir Keir Starmer, the frontrunner to succeed Jeremy Corbyn as Labour leader, claimed Mr Cummings was now becoming so powerful that PMQs in the Commons should become ldquoDCQs.On Mr Sunakrsquos set-piece economic statement, Mr Shapps told Sky Newsrsquos Sophy Ridge on Sunday: "I know the Budget plans are well advanced but I also know Rishi Sunak, the new Chancellor, may want time."I havent heard whether the date of March is confirmed as yet. He is probably looking at it, I should think, this week."Ian Blackford, the SNPrsquos leader at Westminster, has demanded clarity over the date of Budget Day, saying a lack of confirmation was creating increased uncertainty for businesses and others."There is no time for them to dither. Rishi Sunak must confirm the date of the Budget as a matter of urgency," insisted the Highland MP.Mr Sunak, , previously the Treasury Chief Secretary, was catapulted into the top job following Mr Javidrsquos dramatic exit in last weeks Cabinet reshuffle.Speaking on BBCs The Andrew Marr Show, Mr Shapps said the Government was determined to deliver a "big uplt" for infrastructure spending.At the same time he said they would be sticking to their manesto pledge to get debt down over the course of the parliament.The fiscal rules include not borrowing to fund day-to-day spending and that public sector net investment would not average more than three per cent of GDP, guaranteeing debt would be lower at the end of the five-year Parliament than at the beginning.The borrowing of up to three per cent of GDP means the Government has poundbn to spend on infrastructure projects over the next five years. But poundbn has already been committed and it is expected that most of the remaining poundbn will be set out in Mr Sunakrsquos first Budget. Hence, the pressure from within No  for the Treasury taps to be turned on, so that more could be spent on, say, health and social care."Our manesto commitments are our commitments, declared Mr Shapps. ldquoWe absolutely intend to stick to the manesto commitments. For the rest of it, you will need to wait to the Budget," he added.

title: andrew-marr-show-ridge-sunday-reviews
story: The poet was William Hughes Mearns and the verse Antigonish: ldquoYesterday, upon the stair, I met a man who wasnrsquot there He wasnrsquot there again today, I wish I wish he go away.The man who wasnrsquot there was Dominic Cummings, chief special adviser to Boris Johnson. While we are led to believe, not least by Mr Cummingsrsquo supporters, that his influence can be seen everywhere, from the reshuffle to the climate change summit in Glasgow, the man himself is only ever seen striding up Downing Street looking like a teenager who dressed in the dark.: Referendum "absolutely" this yearHis absence on the Sunday politics shows was felt. Take, for instance, what passed for the interview catch of the day on both BBCs The Andrew Marr Show and Sky Newsrsquo Ridge on Sunday: Grant Shapps, Secretary of State for Transport.Ridge addressed the body warmer-wearing elephant in the room directly, asking Mr Shapps about the ldquosack your staff ultimatum that had forced Chancellor Sajid Javid to quit. The demand came from the PM but the idea was said to originate with Mr Cummings.It was not the case, said the Minister, that Mr Cummings, or any other aide, got things all his own way. As an example of this he cited the HS infrastructure project. Mr Cummings had described it as a ldquodisaster zone, but it was given the green light last week.Had he clashed with Mr Johnsonrsquos right hand man, asked Ridge.ldquoClash is the wrong way to describe it, said Mr Shapps, slipping into Yes, Minister parlance. ldquoWe discussed it, our ious views, and we came to a conclusion. The idea that just because Dominic thinks something that is what happens, is clearly not the case.Marr quoted Mr Cummings on HS in his interview with Mr Shapps, but the presenterrsquos focus was less on personalities and more on the Governmentrsquos general direction of travel ndash to wit, getting ready to spend money, and lots of it. Who would be paying, Marr wanted to know.: Budget day could be movedMr Shapps said Marr was trying to draw him on the Budget, a place he refused to venture even to confirmit would be taking place on March  as planned. Speaking of the new Chancellor, Rishi Sunak, Mr Shapps told Marr: ldquoThe guyrsquos only been in place for a few days, letrsquos give him a few days to decide on the date.Mr Cummingsrsquo influence, real or imagined, came up in Ridgersquos interview with Labour leadership candidate Sir Keir Starmer.Asked about last weekrsquos reshuffle, the MP for Holborn and St Pancras said: ldquoDominic Cummings is just getting more and more power. I know Boris Johnson doesnrsquot much like coming to parliament. He does at least come to Prime Ministerrsquos Questions. I think we are going to have to have DCQs, Dominic Cummings Questions, before too long. He is actually holding all the power, and how do we hold him accountable There was one relatively Cummings-free zone and that was Gordon Brewerrsquos interview with Jackson Carlaw, newly elected leader of the Scottish Conservatives, on Sunday Politics Scotland.The Herald on Sunday reported that an increasing number of senior Tories was in favour of holding a second independence referendum. Andy Maciver, the partyrsquos former head of communications turned director of think tank Message Matters, said the ide between those who backed indyref and those who held the ldquoonce in a generation line was going to be the biggest issue the new leader had to face.: Carlaw backs bridge planMr Carlaw denied any split. Butthere was a once in a generation camp, there was no doubt he was in it. He would not back indyref  eventhere was a majority for it in the  Scottish Parliament elections, oropinion poll after opinion poll put support for another vote at -%.ldquoI donrsquot know how you define a generation... but I do know what a generation isnrsquot... itrsquos not five minutes, it is not five years and itrsquos not even a decade, he told Brewer.As the interview drew to a close, Brewer teased that it was now ldquothe bit where you tell us with a completely straight face that yoursquore going to be the next First Minister.Dang it, the MSP for Eastwood almost made it.ldquoI donrsquot think wersquove earned the right to say that yet, he began. ldquoI want to go into the next election by then with a full, alternative policy offering for the people of Scotland. If they vote for it they are voting for the Conservative team and theyrsquoll be voting for me as First Minister to implement it.With that he broke into a chuckle. ldquoHah! said Brewer, ldquoyou gave it away.ldquoI always smile at you Gordon because yoursquore pulling faces at me, said the chief ldquoDr No.Who says politics in Scotland is unfriendly

title: brits-turns-40
story: # Absolutely. title: eels-summit-held-scotland-discuss-conservation
story: Specialists from all over the world will gather at Napier University on April  for the Scottish Eel Conference, which aims to put the critically endangered European eel in the spotlight.Organised by the Forth Rivers Trust, the conference is one of three new initiatives for  designed to help save the fish described as ldquothe worldrsquos most trafficked animal.Two further projects focusing on eels within Scotland will run throughout the year.Included on the World Wildle Foundationrsquos Top Ten Traded Species, the European eel has seen numbers decline by % across the continent in the past  years due to poaching and overfishing to supply markets in Asia.Other threats include water management, water pollution, migration barriers at sluices and pumps, new parasites and diseases, predation from seabirds and possibly climate change.The conference will bring policy makers and leading professionals together at Napierrsquos Craiglockhart Campus to discuss current conservation efforts and the leading science.Talks will focus on the incredible journey of the eel from their breeding place in the Sargasso sea, in the Western Atlantic between the Azores and the Caribbean, to Europe threats facing the fish and the work people across the world are doing to preserve eel species.The summitrsquos aim will be to ldquoengage with conservation groups, government organisations and the public across Scotland and further and show the erse effort and opportunities to save the eel.Jack Wootton, the Trustrsquos Aquatic Ecologist, who will lead the conference, said: ldquoThis mysterious animal still holds many secrets and collective efforts are helping to unveil some of the answers.ldquoFrom the enthusiasm generated by this event we aim to increase the efforts to conserve and understand eels in Scotland as well as ersy funding opportunities for these projects.ldquoWe welcome anyone with an interest in this fascinating animal to join us in Edinburgh on the th of April.ldquoThis is a unique opportunity to be involved in the first eel conference in Scotland and shape the conservation of the species.The Scottish Eel Conference, part of the Scottish-Government-funded ldquoRiverLe: Almond and Avon project, is one of three eel initiatives being developed by the Firth Rivers Trust this year.Running throughout , The Scottish Eel Project will establish population and abundance data across two rivers, the River Leven in Fe and the Midlothian Esks, for the European eel in Scotland, and to increase the understanding of how eels live within our waters.Also running until December , The Forgotten Fish Project uses traditional methods of conservation to tackle current issues affecting the European eel and lessen human effects on the species.

title: cummings-give-evidence-mps-reshuffle---blackford
story: The call has come from Ian Blackford, the SNP leader at Westminster, who has written a letter to the Commons Liaison Committee ndash the committee of all the committee chairmen ndash urging it to summon Mr Cummings, Boris Johnsonrsquos senior No  strategist, to explain ldquohis handling of the UK Governmentrsquos reshuffle.Mr Cummings is regarded as the power behind the Downing St throne whose long-running spat with Mr Javid resulted in the Midlands MP resigning just a month before Budget Day after he refused to comply with the ultimatum of sacking all his advisers in the run-up to the creation of a new economic unit, spanning Nos  and .For many in Whitehall and Westminster this was a naked power-grab by the Prime Minister. He later withdrew his ldquooffer of friendly co-operation,, saying MPs had shown more interest in ldquograndstanding than truth-seeking, which is one of the curses of the committee system.Meanwhile, Grant Shapps, the Transport Secretary, sought to downplay what many regard as Mr Javidrsquos forced departure, stressing how all ministers should be working hand in glove with Downing St and should not be in ldquodferent silos.He insisted it was ldquonot correct to suggest Mr Cummings was running the No  show.Mr Cummings and Mr Javid clashed several times in the seven months the Midlands MP was at the helm of the Treasury. The PMrsquos key adviser was said to be pressing for the Treasury to turn on the spending taps, which the Chancellor was reluctant to do.Mr Shapps denied Mr Cummings was now ldquoall powerful in Whitehall, pointing out how last weekrsquos decision to give the go ahead to the HS high speed rail link was a project opposed by Mr Johnsonrsquos top aide.However, Sir Keir Starmer, the frontrunner to succeed Jeremy Corbyn as Labour leader, claimed Mr Cummings was now becoming so powerful that PMQs in the Commons should become ldquoDCQs.Elsewhere, Mr Shapps suggested Mr Sunak could delay the date of next monthrsquos Budget to give himself more time to prepare for his first major fiscal event.The Secretary of State said ministers had still not been told whether the Budget would go ahead on March  as planned after Sajid Javidrsquos shock resignation.He told Sky Newsrsquos Sophy Ridge on Sunday: ldquoI know the Budget plans are well advanced but I also know Rishihellipmay want time. story: The increase - recorded by estate agent Aberdein Considinersquos Property Monitor report - has been linked to a strong first-time buyer and new build market.Figures show that, across Scotland, more than , homes changed hands in December, the highest figure for the month since  and the credit crunch.This was a  per cent increase on Novemberrsquos figure and the highest single month of sales recorded since October .:Foreign property investors poised to swoop on ScotlandIn the last three months of , East Dunbartonshire saw the biggest increase in transactions, up % on , while Aberdeen and Glasgow also enjoyed boosts of % and .% respectively.Douglas Telfer, Property Partner at Aberdein Considine in Glasgow, said the figures suggest that the market is no longer as seasonal as it used to be.He said: ldquoYou have to go back to December , before the global credit crunch, to find a higher month of pre-Christmas property sales.ldquoIt used to be that you didnrsquot get many sales close to Christmas, but now thatrsquos no longer the case. title: mentoring-permanent-part-glasgows-secondary-schools
story: An independent review of a scheme run by the charity MCR Pathways in Glasgow secondary schools during the past three years found that it had a "signicant" positive impact on children and young people who receive it.The project pairs young people up with a le coach from outside the education system who can pass on advice and prepare them for le after school.The review, carried out by social researchers ScotCen said that mentoring had helped pupils improve their grades and had increased in the number going on to university, college or into employment by more than a quarter.:Why we must change doomed fate of our care-experienced young peopleMCR Pathways currently provides mentors to more than , young people across Scotland and operates in secondary schools in Aberdeenshire, Aberdeen, Clackmannanshire, Edinburgh, North Ayrshire, South Lanarkshire, Shetland and West Dunbartonshire as well as Glasgow.Maureen McKenna, Executive Director of Education, Glasgow City Council said: ldquoThis programme works because we have embedded it within our core business and complements the work of our teacher and school staff ndash nurturing and empowering our most vulnerable young people to believe in themselves regardless of their circumstances."Annemarie OrsquoDonnell, Chief Executive of Glasgow City Council, said: ldquoTo me, as corporate parent to every vulnerable child and young person in our city, the only thing that matters is that we do everything in our collective power to nurture, support and create opportunities that will help them flourish."The research is clear in demonstrating our mentored young people are staying in school longer and achieving more qualications leading to increased options for work, further and higher education. This will unequivocally improve the le chances of these young people.":Le-changing mentoring programme keeps children in school for longer#MCR Founder Iain MacRitchie said: ldquoWe are hugely encouraged by the conclusions of the independent care review. The MCR mentoring programme is already delivering and making a profound dference to the le-chances of our young people."It is fantastic to have MCR permanently embedded in every secondary school in Glasgow. story: The state-of-the-art technology will be managed by the Met Office with the aim of offering more sophisticated rainfall predictions and better forecasting at airports.Todayrsquos announcement comes as Britain suffered its second weekend of high winds and torrential rainfall resulting in floods due to Storm Dennis.Parts of the country were battered by winds of more than mph while in some places more than a monthrsquos worth of rain fell in  hours, leading to a record number of flood warnings and alerts south of the Border.:Scotlands weather: Severe flood warnings remain in force in Scottish BordersPolice declared major incidents in South Wales, Shropshire and Herefordshire.
